DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Says Priest's Slaying May Have Been Politically Motivated
DOC.TEXT: The slaying of a French priest in southeastern Brazil may have been politically motivated and not the work of robbers, a Brazilian archbishop said Wednesday. The Rev. Gabriel Felix Roger Maire ``had been receiving death threats for the past several months due to his work on behalf of justice and human rights for the poor,'' Archbishop Silvestre Scandian said by phone from Vitoria. Police found Maire, 53, shot in the chest and slumped over the wheel of his car Saturday on the outskirts of Vitoria, 310 miles northeast of Rio. Police arrested two suspects and charged them with shooting Maire during an attempted robbery. Scandian disputed the police report, saying Maire's wristwatch and other personal items were left in the car. A bag containing his cassock and empty wallet was found about 100 yards from the scene. The Rev. Mauricio de Mattos Pereira, of the Archdiocese's Justice and Peace Commission, said three other politically motivated killings occurred in nearby towns since June. ``When you try to raise the consciousness of the small, the big react,'' said Pereira. ``They want to silence all those trying to show the poor the roots of injustice.'' Maire arrived in Brazil in 1980 and worked in the lower-class parish of Vila Velha, eight miles south of Vitoria. Thousands of people attended a wake for Maire on Tuesday. The priest's body will be flown to France on Thursday, maccording to Maria Beatrice de Seixas Correa, a spokeswoman at the French consulate in Rio. The Roman Catholic Church here estimates more than 800 people have been assassinated for political reasons since Brazil returned to civilian rule after a right-wing military dictatorship ruled from 1964 to 1985. Many of the victims have been rural union leaders involved in land disputes and church activists who advise them. In only three cases, two involving the murder of priests, have the killers been brought to justice, according to Amnesty International, the human rights group. The most famous case involved the slaying of Chico Mendes, a world-renowned union leader and environmentalist who led peaceful protests to stop the clearing of Amazon rain forest by cattle ranchers. Mendes, 44, was shot in his home in the backwoods Amazon town of Xapuri on Dec. 22, 1988. Although a cattle rancher and his son have been arrested and charged in the case, a judge last week announced that the earliest possible trial date would be April 1990.
